roles.name: Farmer
roles.description: Responsible for planting, cultivating, and harvesting crops or raising livestock. Adopts best practices, manages resources, and ensures product quality.

meta.typicalBackground: Hands-on agricultural experience, knowledge of local climate, soils, markets

sampleUseCase.scenario: A smallholder farmer transitions to a precision irrigation system to save water and increase yields. They receive a government subsidy and technical guidance from an extension officer, leading to a 20% improvement in productivity and reduced water consumption.

roles.name: Agricultural Extension Officer
roles.description: Provides technical advice, training, and support to farmers. Bridges research insights and field applications, promoting new techniques and technologies.

meta.typicalBackground: Formal education in agronomy or related fields, strong communication and demonstration skills

sampleUseCase.scenario: An extension officer hosts a field day showcasing improved seed varieties with higher drought tolerance. They distribute pamphlets, demonstrate proper planting depth, and connect interested farmers to subsidized seeds, raising local yields and reducing crop failure risk.

roles.name: Input Supplier
roles.description: Sells agricultural inputs such as seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, and farming equipment. Provides information on product usage and safety.

meta.typicalBackground: Business or technical sales background, knowledge of agricultural products and regulations
challenges: Managing stock of perishable or regulated products

sampleUseCase.scenario: An input supplier partners with a local cooperative to offer group discounts on organic fertilizers. By leveraging bulk orders and a simplified payment plan, smallholder farmers can afford higher-quality inputs, boosting their productivity and soil health.

roles.name: Aggregator / Cooperative Manager
roles.description: Collects produce from multiple farmers, ensuring consistent quality and quantity. Negotiates with buyers, manages storage or processing facilities, and organizes logistics.

meta.typicalBackground: Experience in supply chain management, basic financial acumen, leadership to coordinate members
challenges: Fair price negotiation with large buyers

sampleUseCase.scenario: A cooperative manager pools maize from 50 smallholders, conducts quality checks, and sells in bulk to a regional buyer. The manager secures a better contract price than each farmer could individually, with earnings distributed back to cooperative members.

roles.name: Food Processor
roles.description: Transforms raw agricultural products into value-added goods (e.g., milling grains, canning vegetables). Maintains quality, food safety, and packaging standards.

meta.typicalBackground: Knowledge of food technology, processing methods, and regulatory compliance

sampleUseCase.scenario: A local miller sources rice from neighboring farms, mills and fortifies it with essential vitamins, then packages it for sale under a regional brand. Quality checks help maintain a loyal customer base and reduce post-harvest losses.

roles.name: Distributor / Wholesaler
roles.description: Buys large volumes of processed or semi-processed goods, handles transport and logistics to move products across regions and markets.

meta.typicalBackground: Expertise in logistics, market demand forecasting, and warehousing
challenges: Fluctuating transport costs (fuel), road conditions, meeting delivery timelines

sampleUseCase.scenario: A wholesaler organizes reefer trucks to collect fresh produce from multiple distribution centers and deliver them to urban retail outlets within 24 hours, maximizing shelf life and reducing spoilage.

roles.name: Retailer
roles.description: Sells food and agricultural products to end consumers. May be supermarkets, local shops, or e-commerce platforms, focusing on product freshness and customer satisfaction.

meta.typicalBackground: Retail management, customer service, marketing, inventory control
challenges: Managing perishable stock, ensuring competitive prices, responding to consumer trends (organic, local, etc.)

sampleUseCase.scenario: A local grocery chain sources fresh fruits from a regional aggregator, highlights ‘farm-to-shelf’ branding. They use loyalty apps to inform customers about new stock, sales, or seasonal produce, boosting repeat business.

roles.name: Researcher / Agronomist
roles.description: Focuses on improving crop varieties, soil health, pest management, and livestock genetics. Conducts experiments, field trials, and publishes findings that inform farming practices.

meta.typicalBackground: Advanced degrees in plant science, soil science, animal science, or related fields
keyTools: Greenhouses, test plots, laboratory equipment, data analysis software
challenges: Securing research funding, ensuring real-world applicability, bridging lab-field gap

sampleUseCase.scenario: An agronomist develops a drought-resistant bean variety through hybridization and field trials. After verifying yield benefits and taste quality, seeds are released to local extension officers who train farmers to adopt them.

roles.name: Government / Policy Maker
roles.description: Sets agricultural policies, subsidies, and regulations that impact everything from land use to food safety. Supports rural development initiatives and oversees compliance.

meta.typicalBackground: Public administration, economics, or political science background, knowledge of agricultural policy
keyTools: Policy frameworks, agricultural census data, budget allocations
challenges: Balancing competing interests (environment, trade, consumer prices), limited public resources

sampleUseCase.scenario: A government official designs a ‘Smart Agriculture’ subsidy program, funding precision irrigation equipment for small farmers. The policy aims to reduce water use while boosting yields, with yearly progress reported in a national agriculture review.

roles.name: NGO / Trade Association
roles.description: Advocates for farmers’ interests, provides capacity-building programs, and addresses social or environmental concerns in agricultural communities.

meta.typicalBackground: Nonprofit management, field experience in development, strong stakeholder engagement
keyTools: Grant funding, training modules, advocacy campaigns
challenges: Dependence on donor funding, coordinating diverse stakeholder agendas, measuring impact effectively

sampleUseCase.scenario: An NGO organizes workshops on integrated pest management, targeting female-led farms in a region prone to crop losses. They also link participants to micro-lenders offering low-interest capital for purchasing safer pesticides.

roles.name: Financial Services / Micro-lender
roles.description: Provides capital or insurance products to farmers, cooperatives, or agri-enterprises. Enables investments in equipment, seeds, or technology, and helps mitigate risks like weather or price volatility.

meta.typicalBackground: Finance or banking, understanding of agricultural cycles and credit risk assessment
challenges: Assessing creditworthiness in rural contexts, weather-related defaults, high transaction costs in remote areas

sampleUseCase.scenario: A microfinance institution develops a weather-indexed insurance product: if rainfall is below a certain threshold, farmers automatically receive a payout. This secures their loan repayments and prevents catastrophic losses from drought.
